results: Geosynthetic inclusions restricted both particle displacements and rotations
Particle displacements were found to be restrained more significantly than rotations
Unique relationship found between permanent strains and zone of probable motions
title:
Quantification of geogrid lateral restraint using transparent sand and
  deep learning-based image segmentation
abstract: An experimental technique is presented to quantify the lateral restraint provided by a geogrid embedded in granular soil at the particle level. Repeated load triaxial tests were done on transparent sand specimens with geosynthetic inclusions simulating geogrids. Particle outlines on laser illuminated planes through the specimens were segmented using a deep learning-based segmentation algorithm. The particle outlines were characterized in terms of Fourier shape descriptors and tracked across sequentially captured images. The accuracy of the particle displacement measurements was validated against Digital Image Correlation (DIC) measurements. In addition, the method's resolution and repeatability is presented. Based on the measured particle displacements and rotations, a state boundary line between probable and improbable particle motions was identified for each test. The size of the zone of probable motions could be used to quantify the lateral restraint provided by the inclusions. Overall, the tests results revealed that the geosynthetic inclusions restricted both particle displacements and rotations. However, the particle displacements were found to be restrained more significantly than the rotations. Finally, a unique relationship was found between the magnitude of the permanent strains of the specimens and the size of the zone of probable motions.
